snippet: Some women, required to wear tracking bracelets as part of a release program from family detention, say the devices are a painful reminder of the circumstances they fled.
abstract: Many undocumented immigrants released from immigration detention centers in United States following decision by federal Judge Dolly M Gee are being required to wear ankle monitors, step immigration advocates call both inhumane and unnecessary; many woman wearing the devices say stigma is negatively affecting their reputations in communities in which they are raising their children.

byline.contributor: Reporting for this article was supported in part by a grant from the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

lead_paragraph: Some women, required to wear tracking bracelets as part of a release program from family detention, say the devices are a painful reminder of the circumstances they fled.

headline.main: Ankle Monitors Weigh on Immigrant Mothers Released From Detention
headline.print_headline: Immigrant Mothers Out of Detention, but Burdened by the Stigma of Ankle Monitors
